evidence: This is the technology used in nearly all current CT scanners.
Instead of summing all energies together, photon-counting detectors measure each incoming photon individually and record its energy.
A variation of this is dual-energy imaging, where two different energy spectra are used to give some limited energy discrimination.
That means they can separate photons into different energy bins, giving us spectral information.
With this approach, we can do material decomposition, K-edge imaging, and molecular-level X-ray imaging.
